}}</ref> The ad cited two ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' articles to support its claims. However, the editor for ''Science'' stated that the ad "misrepresents the conclusions of the two cited ''Science'' papers... by selective referencing". The author of the articles also objected to the ad, stating that the ad was a "deliberate effort to confuse and mislead the public about the global warming debate."
}}</ref> The ad cited two ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' articles to support its claims. However, the editor for ''Science'' stated that the ad "misrepresents the conclusions of the two cited ''Science'' papers... by selective referencing". The author of the articles also objected to the ad, stating that the ad was a "deliberate effort to confuse and mislead the public about the global warming debate."

They call it pollution. We call it life."<ref name=factcheck /> However, many scientific organizations have stressed the danger of excess carbon dioxide in the earth's atmosphere; in [[June]] [[2005]], the science academies of 11 leading industrial nations (including the [[National Academy of Sciences]]) released a statement listing carbon-dioxide as a [[greenhouse gas]], which is "causing temperatures to rise."<ref name=factcheck />
